Award.AwardTitle: Materials World Network: A New Generation of Optical and Magnetooptical Nonlinear Materials Based on Plasmonic Gain Composites
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
The main objective of this research is to develop a theoretical framework capable of making practical recommendations for the design of new spaser (surface plasmon amplification by stimulated emission of radiation) based metamaterials with strong nonlinear response to low intensity optical fields. Since spasers were discovered only recently, their description has relied on simplistic models. With support from the Division of Materials Research, this Materials World Network project will carry out analytical and numerical calculations using a realistic model that takes into account the anisotropy of interactions of the spaser's component parts, which allow for excitation of magnetic modes that are essential for metamaterials. Metamaterials suffer from an unacceptable level of Joule losses. Moreover, for metamaterial based devices it is necessary not only to overcome these losses but to achieve exact compensation. The purpose of this research project is to demonstrate that spasers, as active inclusions in metamaterials and magnetooptical materials, are ideal candidates for achieving this goal. For metaplasmonics, it is important to consider not a single spaser but a system of spasers, such as ordered chains and lattices. The collective interaction of spasers in such a system may substantially change generation conditions, properties of auto-oscillations, and may engender new phenomena and instabilities. With Russian and US teams working in collaboration, the project will study the collective behavior of a system of spasers in an external electromagnetic field including spaser synchronization by the external field as well as their mutual synchronization.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
In the last decade, the field of quantum nanoplasmonics has experienced explosive growth due to numerous anticipated revolutionary applications in optics, which are expected to lead to the future development of ultrafast and supersmall optoelectronic devices. Nanoplasmonics utilizes outstanding optical properties of metal nanoparticles, which when combined with a nanoscale active medium, results in the emergence of a "spaser" (surface plasmon amplification by stimulated emission of radiation), which is a nanoplasmonic counterpart of the laser. Since spasers were discovered only recently, their description is based on simplistic models. In this Materials World Network project, a novel realistic model of spasers will be developed. This model will reveal new properties of spasers, such as magnetic modes, which are crucial for applications of artificial materials having unusual properties "metamaterials." Applications of metamaterials have been inhibited by high levels of energy loss. The proposed project will demonstrate that this drawback can be overcome with the help of spasers. Metamaterials with spaser inclusions provide an ideal low-cost platform for future optical devices. This study will extend the fundamental understanding of the light-matter interaction at the nanoscale. This proposal will facilitate international contacts between US and Russian research institutions. Graduate and undergraduate students from diverse social, ethnic and national backgrounds will be involved in the research. They will be exposed to the research at the collaborating institutions in an effort to acquaint them with complementary methods, approaches, and techniques that will broaden their scientific horizons.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the course of the project, we made a number of findings that have an impact on fundamentals of the physics of nanoplasmonics. Some of the obtained results are important for practical applications. Among fundamental and practical findings are:

It was claimed in the literature that plasmonic nanolasers (spasers) are impractical because, in applications, they would be burned by pumping. We demonstrated that this is incorrect for spasers interacting with an external electromagnetic field. Such spasers driven by an external wave could be used in a variety of applications including for loss compensation in metamaterials.

In the last decade, the interest to feature rich optical systems that possess parity-time (PT) symmetry has been steadily growing. One of the most impressive results obtained in this field was a possibility of symmetry breaking phase transitions while varying the frequency of the external field. We proved that such a phenomenon would violate causality, and therefore, could not be observed. This theorem effectively closes the area of research of such transitions.

The magneto-optical effect is widely used to manipulate light. However, the magneto-optical response of natural media is relatively weak so that enhancements of magneto-optical properties are highly desirable. We showed that a periodic chain of interacting spasers embedded into a magneto-optical medium might increase the magneto-optical effect by two orders of magnitude.

For more than six decades, it has been commonly accepted that a superradiant burst from a subwavelength array of emitters is only possible when the system is in the special state – the Dicke state. We showed that for both nonlinear classical and quantum emitters such a state is not necessary. We suggested a mechanism for the emergence of a superradiance burst that does not require the Dicke state.

Even though substantial progress has been made in creating plasmonic distributed feedback (DFB) lasers, many issues remain unsolved. The main problem with a DFB laser is that a plasmonic system has high losses and, thereby, a high value of the first lasing threshold. This necessitates using high-gain active media, which overheats the laser. We demonstrated that the widespread belief that an increase in the gain coefficient of an active medium of the laser leads to an increase of the laser output is not necessarily correct. We showed that there is an optimum value for the gain coefficient of a plasmonic DFB laser. If the value of the gain coefficient exceeds the optimum value, the laser characteristics suffer. We believe that this is an important discovery that may lead to a substantial increase in the laser efficiency while eliminating the necessity of increasing the pump power. We also discovered a new mechanism for lasing generation via loss in DFB lasers. This mechanism works when the frequency of the transition line of the amplifying medium differs from the laser mode frequency.

We demonstrated a counterintuitive possibility of exciting an atom by a superoscillating external field all spectral components of which are outside of the absorption band of the atom.

Intracavity laser spectroscopy methods are known to have an extremely high sensitivity. The main problem with this method is that a laser using dye molecules in a polymer matrix as an active medium lives for only one millisecond. We theoretically demonstrated and participated in the experimental implementation of intracavity plasmonic laser spectroscopy using a plasmonic laser created from a periodically-perforated silver film with a liquid gain medium. The plasmonic sensor that we developed retains advantages of all known systems of this type but has a much longer practical life of the matrix allowing for multiple uses of the sensor. This work provided opportunities for developing applications of intracavity plasmonic laser spectroscopy in biological label detection and other fields.

As of today, quantum nanoplasmonics is an exciting field of fundamental research, but it is far from practical applications. The main reason for that is that surface plasmon polaritons can be utilized in applications only if they have a propagation length of hundreds of nanometers, strong confinement in the direction perpendicular to the surface, and a short wavelength. As of today, in the visible part of the spectrum, these conditions are not satisfied for any surface plasmon polaritons. We suggested a system that utilizes a nanostructure metal-dielectric interface that in the ultraviolet region, could maintain surface plasmon polariton modes with all characteristics necessary for miniaturization of optical devices.

The results of the studies pertaining to the projected were reported at numerous national and international conferences and published in 25 papers in peer-refereed journals, four reviews and a book “Quantum Nanoplasmonics.”

We strengthened our collaboration with the counterpart institution, Moscow Institute for Physics and Technology. We also involved Russian physicists from Institute of Spectroscopy of the Russian Academy of Sciences, National Research University, and Bauman Moscow State Technical University into this collaboration.
